_meanings:
{@--1@} Placing at
the head of, appointing &c.

{@--3@}
(In <ab>gram.</ab>) Agreement, concord, 
government or grammatical relation (as
of subject and predicate &c.); {#tatpuruzaH#}
{#samAnADikaraRaH karmaDArayaH#} <ls>P. I. 2. 42</ls>
having the members (of the 
compound) in the same relation or
apposition; {#samAnADikaraRo#} or  

{#vyaDikaraRo bahuvrIhiH; pItAMbaraH, cakrapARiH#} &c.

{@--4@}
A receptacle or subject, technically
substratum; {#jYAnADikaraRaM AtmA#} <ls>T. S.</ls>
the soul is the substratum of 
knowledge.

{@--6@} A
topic, subject; section, article or 
paragraph; a complete argument treating of
one subject; the Sūtras of Vyāsa and
Jaimini are divided into Adhyāyas,
the Adhyāyas into Pādas and the 
Pādas into Adhikaraṇas or sections. 
According to the Mīmāṃsakas a 
complete Adhikaraṇa consists of five
members:-- {#vizaya#} the subject or 
matter to be explained, {#viSaya#} or {#saMSaya#}
the doubt or question arising upon
that matter, {#pUrvapakza#} the first side or
{%prima facie%} argument concerning
it, {#uttara#} or {#uttarapakza#} or {#sidDAMta#} the 
answer or demonstrated conclusion,
and {#saMgati#} pertinency or relevancy,
or (according to others {#nirRaya#} the
final conclusion); {#vizayo viSayaScEva#} 
{#pUrvapakzastaTottaraM . nirRayaSceti sidDAMtaH SAstre'#} 
{#DikaraRaM smftam ..#} The Vedāntins put {#saMgati#}
in the 3rd place, and {#sidDAMta#} last; {#tatra#}
{#ekEkamaDikaraRaM paMcAvayavaM, vizayaH saMdehaH saMgatiH#}
{#pUrvapakzaH sidDAMtaSca#}. Generally speaking,
the five members may be taken to be
{#vizaya, saMSaya, pUrvapakza, uttarapakza#} and {#sidDAMta#} or
{#rAdDAMta#}.
